contentData.text:
St Philemon's is a church where anyone can encounter God. We have a message of life at its fullest. It comes for free, and everyone is invited to be a part of it. 

 

Have a browse to get a feel for what we are about. But most of all, we'd love to meet you in person. You would be welcome to come to anything you see here. And there is never pressure on you to come back.

contentData.title: Read more
contentData.text:
As part of the Church of England, we have been meeting together for over 140 years. We aren't religious. For us, church is all about authentic relationships - both with God and each other.

 

Our church family is made up of a huge range of people. God is at work among us, to unite us under the Lord Jesus Christ and with one another. It's messy but it's great!

 

In the recent past, every year St Philemon's has got bigger... and younger... and more generous... and more able to do more for the community around us. It's exciting, and we invite you to see it for yourself.

contentData.title: Jesus makes God known
contentData.text:
Jesus is the most famous person in human history, and it is Jesus that Christianity is all about. It is where the term Christian comes from, because Jesus was called the Christ, which means God’s anointed King.

 

Lots of people have vague ideas about Jesus, some from half-remembered school lessons, others from things that they’ve seen or heard on the TV. But not a lot of people know what the firsthand evidence says about Jesus and what he was like. 

 

This eye-witness evidence is all found in the Bible

 

We all look at the world around us and try to guess what God is like. Some of us guess that there is no God at all, some of us guess that God is distant and has left us to our own devices, some of us guess something else entirely. Unless God shows us who he is and what he is like, all we can ever do is guess.

 

But the Bible tells us that showing us who he is is exactly what God has done! He came to earth in real history as the man Jesus. He lived, worked and spent time with real people showing them, and us, what he is like.

 

(Look further: John 1:1-15)

contentData.title: Jesus is loving
contentData.text:
Jesus’ whole life was characterised by a genuine love for everyone that he met. Jesus famously called little children back to play near him after his followers tried to send them away, thinking that Jesus was too important to be disturbed by children playing. He also looked after the sick, the marginalised and the outcasts of society, and welcomed everyone who came to him regardless of age, race, gender or class.

 

(Look further: Luke 19:1-8, John 4:4-28)

contentData.title: Jesus is powerful
contentData.text:
Jesus wasn’t just an ordinary man. He performed all sorts of miraculous signs to show that he was in fact God in human form.

 

In Mark 4 we hear the story of Jesus calming a storm. Not the kind of thing that a normal person can do, and very similar to the story of Jonah, where it is God who calms the storm.

 

In Mark 2 a paralysed man has his sins forgiven by Jesus and is then healed. The Jewish people in the room with Jesus know that he was claiming to be God by his actions.

 

Jesus performed many miracles throughout his life, including healing people, providing food for thousands of people, even raising dead people back to life, all to show that we cannot listen to his teaching thinking that he was just a man, but that we have to recognise that he was God in human form.

 

(Look further: Mark 3:1-6, Mark 5:21-42, Mark 6:30-56)

contentData.title: Jesus came to rescue
contentData.text:
We have all lived in God’s world, but none of us has not honoured him perfectly in all that we do. The Bible calls this sin, and it means that none of us deserve God’s love and care; instead we deserve his judgment for our rebellion against him.

 

We can’t rescue ourselves from this judgment, but God has provided a way to rescue us. That is why Jesus came.

 

Even before Jesus came, God had promised this rescue. Here is how one prophet, Isaiah, writing hundreds of years before Jesus came, put it:

 

‘We all, like sheep, have gone astray, each of us has turned to our own way; 
and the Lord has laid on him the iniquity of us all.’

 

Jesus didn’t come just as an example to us of how we should live. He came to live the life we should have lived for us, and then to take upon himself the just punishment for the lives we actually have lived - in our place.

 

That is why Jesus died on a cross. He didn’t deserve to die. He was completely innocent of all wrongdoing. But he didn’t die against his wishes either, as if he were unable to do anything about it. He chose to die, as a sacrifice in the place of all people who wish to put their trust in him.

 

And three days later, Jesus rose to life again, showing that he had fully paid the price for all our sin and that he is more powerful than death, so we can trust him with our own deaths, and have confidence that he will raise us to new lives with him!

 

(Look further: John 1:1-15)

contentData.title: Jesus will judge
contentData.text:
One day Jesus will come back, and will judge all people for how they have lived.

 

God’s standard is perfection. So if we rely on our own abilities when Jesus judges, every one of us is guilty of sin, and so will face God’s punishment, which is to be cast away from every good thing in the world.

 

But if we put our trust in Jesus, he has already completely paid the penalty for our sin, and so we will not be condemned. When Jesus judges he will re-create the world into a perfect place where he will rule as King forever. If we have put our trust in Jesus to rescue us, we can live in this perfect world with Jesus forever.

 

(Look further: Romans 2:1-16)

Most basically, we believe that the true and living God (Father, Son and Holy Spirit) is amazing: he’s beautiful, majestic, faithful, kind and generous; in fact he’s better than we could possibly imagine, and the very meaning of life is to get to know him. Everyone lives for something, and we want to live for him.

 

As a church, we believe just what Christians always have believed. You can find it laid out in the Apostles’ Creed, the Church of England’s 39 Articles, or this helpful video. We ask anyone who preaches in our church to sign assent to the Jerusalem Declaration.

 

Our church's fundamental aim is to seek to bring God glory. We aim to do this by being...

contentData.title: A growing church
contentData.text:
No-one at Philly's thinks they're perfect.

 

In fact it’s just the opposite! We all have doubts, problems, wounds and struggles. And the church as a whole has lots of issues too. But we believe that God is at work in us by his Spirit to help us know him and to make us better, happier, stronger, braver and more content. We want this, even if God has to challenge our pride, our habits, or the little idols we worship along the way.  

 

Change is scary but we’re in it together. Under God we are all seeking to care for and disciple each other. That means it should be easy for anyone to join us for the journey. And we love it that more and more people are.

contentData.title: ...listening to the Bible
contentData.text:
When the Bible is faithfully taught, we hear God speak to us – and there is no sweeter word.

 

To the surprise of many, the Bible is not primarily about what we have to do for God. It's about what he has done for us through the cross of Christ. Our experience is that this message of grace sets us wonderfully free. When we listen to the Bible and live it out, God’s Spirit gets active in our lives. And then anything can happen!

contentData.title: ...in the heart of Toxteth
contentData.text:
We think this is a great place to live: we are committed to it and want to invest in its future.

 

We want to do whatever we can to serve our community. It is our beating heart to share with people the things from God that have helped us. More than that, because each individual in Toxteth has been made by God, we believe that everyone else has lots to offer too. We want to be a church where absolutely anyone will find a warm welcome and a vision for the difference they can make.
Here are a few of our church family to give you a feel for who we are.
See more...
Partners

God’s kingdom is much bigger than our little church, so we work in partnership with other churches and Christian organisations, and commit to giving at least 10% of our income to support them.

 

Here are some of our partners:

contentData.title: How do people get more involved?
contentData.text:
Serving is one of the best and quickest ways to build strong friendships, make a difference in the lives around you, and grow closer to God. If you have a particular passion or skill, or would just like to contribute to the Philly's community, we’d love to hear from you!

 

There are lots of ways you might help. We try to put you in a team so it's not isolating. And we will make it easy for you to stop or slow down if you ever want to.

 

After people have been with us for about three months, we offer them the opportunity to meet up with one of our church leaders to talk intentionally about how they are finding things and whether they might like to get involved in serving others. But if we have missed you, you don't want to wait that long, or you want to have the conversation again, just fill out a Connect card one Sunday.

contentData.title: How practically can I pray and give?
contentData.text:
Jesus tells us that most of our praying and giving should be done in secret. So at Philly's we don't tend to pass a collection basket around, and the treasurer is the only person who knows who gives what. Nevertheless, praying and giving are two of the great expressions of faith, love and hope in action.

 

In the resources area of church, you will find a monthly church prayer diary. It is filled with up-to-date, relevant things to pray about, both for the church and beyond. The prayer diary is also easy to install on most phones and tablets. Install the free app ‘PrayerMate’ and you’ll find it under ‘subscribe to online content’. If you have any problems, someone in church can help you set it up.

 

There are a variety of ways to give money to St Philemon's. Our most preferred way of giving is by Direct Debit, using the Parish Giving Scheme. This is easy both to set up and change at any time, and is the route that the Church of England encourages. For more information, please contact our treasurer, Phil Smith (treasurer@stphilemons.co.uk). 

 

You can give by bank transfer (St Philemon’s church, HSBC bank, sort code 40-29-12, account no. 11827537). You can use the response box at the back of church to give by cash or cheque (payable to St Philemon's Church). If you are a tax-payer, please make a Gift Aid declaration, which will increase the value of your gift to us by 25% at no cost to yourself.

contentData.title: Hiring one of our buildings
contentData.text:
We welcome use of our buildings by the local community. We have the church building (78 Admiral Street) and the St John's Centre building (2 Steble Street).

You can read our policy here. For all enquiries contact the church office.

contentData.title: Baptisms and Thanksgivings
contentData.text:
For all enquiries contact the church office.

 

Thanksgivings for infants: In a thanksgiving service we praise God for his gift of the baby and thank him for the skill of the medical staff and the love of friends and family. We then commit the baby's future to God and ask him to bless them. 

 

St Philemon’s would be delighted to host a thanksgiving service for you on almost any Sunday of your choice. There is no charge, no requirement to attend church normally, and no preparation required. We can also host a party at the church afterwards for you, if you like. 

 

Baptisms for adults and young people: For those who are old enough to think and speak for themselves, baptism is a sign that they have become a Christian. In the baptism service we make serious promises to God, so it is important that we understand these promises and make them from the heart. 

For that reason we ask any adult or young person who wants to explore baptism to attend a preparation course first. These courses usually happen in a group setting but we can arrange one to suit you. 

 

Baptisms for infants: In the case of those too young to make a decision for themselves, baptism is sign of what their parents hope for them, namely that they will grow up as Christian believers and never remember a time when they weren’t. As for adults, the baptism service involves the making of serious promises, in this case made by parents and godparents.

For anyone who would like to have their child baptised, the first step is to have a thanksgiving service (see above).
